Posts.Content: I was put into "chemical menopause" with a Zoladex-Femara combination.  The Hot Flashes are pretty frequent and annoying.  (I frequently get a tinge of nausea with each episode.)  Haven't counted how many times during the day, but it's frequent.  I'm getting some joint and bone pain -- exercise helps A LOT.  When I brought up the hot flash problem with an older friend, she smiled.  She's never been on any meds, but has been in menopause for a few years now.  She said she carries a handkerchief & the sweat just pours off of her!  Just one of those "gifts" I guess.  :)  It's hard for us to know, as our bodies didn't just naturally take us there.  On plus side, many of the studies I've read state that the sweats show the lack of estrogen (thus the lack of "food" for invading cells to use), the better our beating any return of breast cancer cells...  I've taken to mopping my forehead and saying, "Thank You, Lord; You're healing me!"  :)
Posts.Title: Hot Flashes AFTER Femara?

Posts.Content: 3 1/2 weeks ago I was diagnosed with ILC.  A PET scan is scheduled to be done this week.  I did come across a study at MD Anderson that suggested ILC (as opposed to Ductal carcinomas) usually do not shrink with preoperative chemo.   I found a lump with self exam - the follow-up mammogram was not conclusive; a sonogram & biopsy were required. For the same reasons you stated -- an increased probability (with ILC) of being found in the other breast; the complications with later/future reconstruction; and my own genealogy, I too am opting for a double mastectomy.  My surgeon was very thorough in instructing me, re my options.  But like you, I do not want to imagine myself walking through this again any time soon. I feel this is the best option for me.  Thanks for sharing.  Hope you are doing great!
Posts.Title: bctn surgery first or chemo

Posts.Content: I experienced this, regularly, approximately a year to a year and a half before my diagnosis of lobular carcinoma.  It was so noticeable that I began "logging" the events, as they occurred every 10 to 15 minutes.   I haven't experienced it since; but I remember wondering if the 2 were related -- they were like small electrical "currents" -- not really painful, but VERY noticeable.
Posts.Title: strange sensation

Posts.Content: Hi ALL  One of my neighbors (Newly Diagnosed) just began chemo treatments.  She's had 2 -- The first lasted about 7 hours.  The second with Herceptin.  (The breast cancer is Her2+)   Since the 2 chemo treatments, she is experiencing debilitating migraine headaches, and is considering quitting chemo treatments.   Has anyone else out there experienced migraines?  Have any of you found an "answer" for them?   I'd really appreciate any info to pass along to her.   THANK YOU for responding!
Posts.Title: Migraine Headaches

Posts.Content: eternalife -- The initial biopsy report showed ER+, PR+ and HerNeu- Is that what you are referring to ?   I am going to ask for testing for BrCa1/2, as there is potential family history.
Posts.Title: Newbie - PET Scan Showing lesions in bone of Spine

Posts.Content: Tired55 - Thanks for writing!  Yes; it seems too-much-too-fast to try to get your/my head around.  Have been doing as much as I can on my end to read (voraciously), pray, keep moving, and enjoy the many blessed moments in each of my days.  I had been scheduled to have a bi-lateral mastectomy a couple weeks ago, but when the PET scan & biopsy reported lesions in my spine, the surgery was postphoned 'til that could be dealt with. Apparently, lobular breast cancer cells respond more to endocrine (hormone) therapy than to chemo.  I met with the oncologist on Monday (she's great); was started on Xgeva and Zoladex in order to starve the cells of estrogen & progesterone.  (It's throwing me into chemical menopause -- already getting hot flashes/flushes). Will Start taking Femara next week to build up the bone tissue in order to kick out this invader. They're Monitoring blood tests and size of breast tumor every 4 weeks; then look at surgery (mastectomy or partial) in 2-3 months.  I'm using this time to eat as best I can; exercise; play; pray; and organize.  I'd be glad to write back and forth any time.  It does Help to talk with someone else who's battling the same thing.  Already Understand all too well the waiting game and "mind battles" that go on along the way.  So Thanks again for writing.   --planeK
Posts.Title: Newbie - PET Scan Showing lesions in bone of Spine

Posts.Content: Re: writing -- You bet! -- Sure helps me too! Since the tumor was 7 cm, did they recommend radiation therapy?   The radiology doctor told me he would recommend it if above 5 cm...   but I know it's each person's choice ; as you've already done a bilateral mastectomy.  i'm trying to make a choice there as well -- will depend on the size of the tumor in a couple months for me, I think.   The tumor seemed to be growing a bit (mine's on the right side); but I wonder how much of that is from the stereotactic biopsy irritating the area ... too many passes to get samples. I just don't know.  Did they have to remove some of your lymph glands too?  So far, mine appear to be clear.  (Thankful for that!)   Hope you have a GREAT day!   --caseye
Posts.Title: Newbie - PET Scan Showing lesions in bone of Spine

Since the tumor was 7 cm, did they recommend radiation therapy?   The radiology doctor told me he would recommend it if above 5 cm...   but I know it's each person's choice ; as you've already done a bilateral mastectomy.  i'm trying to make a choice there as well -- will depend on the size of the tumor in a couple months for me, I think.   The tumor seemed to be growing a bit (mine's on the right side); but I wonder how much of that is from the stereotactic biopsy irritating the area ... too many passes to get samples. I just don't know.  Did they have to remove some of your lymph glands too?  So far, mine appear to be clear.  (Thankful for that!)   Hope you have a GREAT day!   --caseye
Posts.Title: Newbie - PET Scan Showing lesions in bone of Spine

Posts.Content: I will check with my oncologist about this next week...  I was scheduled to have bi-lateral mastectomy today; but after a PET scan showed "suspicious" lesions in the bones of my spine, the surgery was cancelled for a biopsy (which, if positive for mets) would mean chemo.  I haven't asked about follow-on surgery yet, but will see what the general concensus of opinion is with the group here.  Wishing you the best.  --k
Posts.Title: surgery after 15 months

Posts.Content: Hi.  I'm new to all of this.  Was told last month that the bump in my Right breast was Invasive Lobular Carcinoma. Now got a call that the pre-op PET Scan is showing lesions in the bone of my spine... ?  Wow!  --  Back to back -- Can't even get my head around this.   Has anybody had this happen all at once?  Can you please write something to me?  I have one of those jobs that requires an on-going health certification, so am suddenly out of a job ("medically unfit") and trying to "cope" with it all.   A CT-guided bone biopsy (needle) is being scheduled next week.   I have a strong faith.  Still; this side-swiped me.  Twice. Thanks if you have a moment to write. --Plane K
Posts.Title: Newbie - PET Scan Showing lesions in bone of Spine

Posts.Content: THANK YOU for writing/responding!  I really appreciated your sharing and encouragement.  That's awesome that you are in remission!  I'm still in the "running tests" group -- they did an MRI on my spine yesterday to help in running an upcoming CT-guided bone biopsy.  I am doing what I know to do -- reading/educating myself; eating vegetables (especially dark greens), fruit, fish, whole-grain, etc.  Walking/jogging 2 to 3 miles a day; swimming; and trying to not get too bogged down.  I know I have people praying for me - that helps a lot more than they realize.  Thanks so much for answering.  It really helped my day.  ==just plane k
Posts.Title: Newbie - PET Scan Showing lesions in bone of Spine

Posts.Content: Yes, the wait gets heavy.  Added to the fact that Every time I feel a whisper of discomfort or pressure it's difficult not to flinch or walk into the "what-if's"...   The bone biopsy report came back that the lobular breast cancer is showing as mets to various places in the bones (and bone marrow?) of the spine.  The oncologist just called me with that Friday night.  Meeting with the oncologist tomorrow to discuss treatment plans/options.   Sounds like Endocrine (hormone) therapy to reduce the mets and the tumor, followed by surgery, followed by chemo.   Will know more after tomorrow.  THANK YOU for your encouragement to Keep the Faith.   Blessings! --k
Posts.Title: Newbie - PET Scan Showing lesions in bone of Spine

Posts.Content: A good friend of mine had similar scan report discrepancy - arthritis apparently looks similar to cancer lesions on MRI's.  His turned out to be arthritis.     So... In order to be sure in my situation, we did a PET, and then followed it with a bone biopsy.   Hope that's helpful.
Posts.Title: very confused about stage 4 bc
